abstract: Comcast tries to explain BitTorrent blocking reports. It manages the traffic for the average user and sometimes larger users of the pipes will find their content delayed, not blocked, the company says.
snippet: Comcast tries to explain BitTorrent blocking reports. It manages the traffic for the average user and sometimes larger users of the pipes will find their content delayed, not blocked, the company says.
lead_paragraph: Last week, the folks at cable giant Comcast asked for more time to give a nuanced response to a report that the company was blocking some peer-to-peer traffic on its network. The public relations staff at the Philadelphia company seemed genuinely baffled by accusations that it was interfering with file-sharing applications like BitTorrent and Gnutella. They stubbornly insisted that they did not monitor or block any Internet traffic – despite strong evidence to the contrary.

headline.main: Comcast: We’re Delaying, Not Blocking, BitTorrent Traffic

abstract: Comcast endures technical errors during its defense of Internet blocking
snippet: Comcast endures technical errors during its defense of Internet blocking
lead_paragraph: My post yesterday left out the funniest part of my conversation with Comcast, in which the cable company demonstrated some of the bonus features of its new telephone network.

headline.main: That Comcastic Voice and Data Network
